FacilityName: Carroll Boone Freeman Raney Water Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Carroll  Boone Water District, (CBWD) of Eureka Springs, Arkansas takes water from Beaver Lake, treats it to a potable level and distributes it to public entities located in Carroll and Boone Counties in Arkansas.

Carroll  Boone Water District stores both Anhydrous Ammonia and Chlorine at the Freeman  Raney water treatment plant.  However, the maximum quantity of Anhydrous Ammonia which may be stored is 4,300 pounds. Therefore, Anhydrous Ammonia is not regulated.

The Maximum quantity of Chlorine which may be stored is 16,000 pounds.  Chlorine is regulated by 40 CFR 68  Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.

Carroll  Boone Water District certifies that they have had no reportable accidents within the last five (5) years.  

The worst-case release scenario considered is a full 2,000 pound container of chlorine released in 10 minutes.  The distance to worst-case toxic endpoint is 2.23 miles.  Calculations by RMP Comp with Mitigation considered is that containers are in enclosed space in direct contact w/outside air  shed w/1 side open

The alternative release scenario considered, is a full 2,000 pound container released through a broken 5/16 inch container valve in 133 minutes.  The distance to alternative toxic endpoint is 0.20 miles. Calculations by RMP Comp with Mitigation considered is that containers are in enclosed space in direct contact w/outside air  shed w/1 side open.

There are public receptors, residencies and U.S. Army Corps of Engineer Recreation Areas, within the worst case toxic end point.  Therefore CBWD Freeman  Raney Water Treatment Plant Program Level is Program 2.

The Program 2 Accidental Release Prevention Program is directed toward reduction of the probability of accidental releases of chlorine at this location.  The program addresses management, the adequacy of chlorination equipment and operator proficiency to eliminate or reduce such accidental chlorine releases.

The Freeman  Raney Water Treatment Plant is included in the

written community emergency response plan  Carroll County Office of Emergency Services Emergency Response Plan.  Therefore, CBWDs emergency response plan is limited to their action plan to contact the Carroll County Office of Emergency Services to initiate emergency response services.

Carroll  Boone Water Districts Emergency Response Coordinator is the Plant Manager.  In his absence, the Safety Manager will be in charge.  In the absence of both, the senior staff on premise will act as the Emergency Response Coordinator, (ERC) until the arrival of the Plant Manager and/or Safety Manager.  The ERC will coordinate responsibility and assist first responders upon their arrival.

The Carroll  Boone Water District hosted an informal meeting at the Freeman  Raney Water Treatment Plant on May 12, 1999 of parties contributing to prevention program and which have responsibilities in implementation of the Emergency Response Program.
